Crimes.Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Inadequate analysis of the best interests of the child
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider child's suffering and financial implications of removal
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application allowed, matter referred for redetermination

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada after visa expiry
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, faced abuse in Grenada, has Canadian-born child
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary resident overstayer seeking permanent residency
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Inadequate assessment of humanitarian and compassionate factors
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer dismissed evidence of hardship without sufficient reasoning
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different immigration officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to properly consider best interests of the child and applicant's hardships

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Inadequate consideration of child's best interests
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned, case referred for reassessment
Evidence_Type: Lack of ties to home country
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on family unity and child welfare
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess emotional and financial impact on child
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Careful, sympathetic, and distinct consideration of child's best interests
Evidence_Ignored: Likelihood of child relocating with parent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Child’s deep roots in Canada and lack of connection to country of origin
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application allowed, matter referred to new officer

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their visa, relying on family reunification and the best interests of their grandchild; minimal evidence provided, such as a letter stating moral support
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review filed to challenge decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Decision made by immigration officer under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to demonstrate unusual hardship or compelling humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No explicit credibility concerns raised, but limited evidence weakened claim
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Exemption from requirement to apply for permanent residency from abroad
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual hardship must be proven if required to apply from abroad
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer found insufficient grounds for exemption; child's primary ties were with parents, not applicants

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration status violation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada beyond authorized stay and applied for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on family ties
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to prolonged stay without valid status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review to assess reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Decision falls under federal immigration jurisdiction
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of substantial evidence demonstrating unique hardship or deep integration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse findings, but evidence deemed insufficient
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from applying for permanent residency from outside Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permanent residency based on family reunification and best interests of child
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to prove unusual hardship if applying from abroad
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer found insufficient proof of hardship or exceptional circumstances; primary familial responsibility rests with parents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of H&C exemption refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper application of 'disproportionate hardship' test instead of 'best interests' test for children
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed, but evidence was disregarded
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on family ties and children's welfare
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of the children must be considered separately from hardship analysis
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied disproportionate hardship standard to children's best interests
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child standard under s. 25
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence on risk in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Application_Factor: Children’s psychological well-being and safety risks in country of origin
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, case remanded

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Authorization to Return to Canada requirements
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of H&C exemption refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Incorrect legal test applied for assessing children's best interests
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's past misconduct considered but not determinative
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate relief based on family ties and children's welfare
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Separate consideration of children's best interests required
Crimes.Application_Error: Blended disproportionate hardship and best interests analyses
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child as a distinct factor
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence on risks in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Application_Factor: Impact of removal on children’s mental health and safety
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, case remanded

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of H&C exemption refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Correct legal test for assessing children's best interests and hardship
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Partial consideration of risk evidence in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate H&C grounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Best interests of children must be assessed separately from hardship
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Family ties and children's welfare in Canada
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Success on judicial review due to legal error
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s. 25 – Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Emphasis on applicant’s non-compliance and prior removal

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of H&C exemption refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper use of disproportionate hardship test for children's best interests
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's past conduct noted but outweighed by procedural errors
Evidence_Type: Risk evidence related to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian grounds based on children's welfare and family life
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mandatory separate assessment of children's best interests
Crimes.Application_Error: Used hardship standard for best interests analysis
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child under s. 25
Crimes.Application_Factor: Potential harm to children if returned to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation at border or in re-entry documentation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving credibility and document authenticity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in concluding the applicant submitted fraudulent documents and lacked credibility
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant's refugee claim rejected due to inconsistencies and fraudulent documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found significant discrepancies between PIF, oral testimony, and documents; lack of credibility confirmed
Evidence_Type: Lack of police reports or corroborating evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Submission of fraudulent documents and inconsistent statements
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide consistent information and supporting documentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk upon return
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in personal information, testimony, and documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review; RPD decision upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Letter from Harun Al-Rashid deemed unreliable and potentially fabricated

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual claiming persecution as a victim of terrorist threats
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Claims of ongoing threats from terrorist organizations
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant's psychological condition affecting memory and testimony
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of harm if returned to home country
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted threats based on perceived opposition to terrorist group
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Low, due to inconsistencies and embellishments
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found credibility issues despite mental health considerations

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving failure to report persecution and seek state protection
Crimes.Outcome: Claim rejected due to lack of credible reporting and corroboration
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by terrorists in absence of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law and domestic implementation under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Institutional_Action: RPD assessed credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant under threat from non-state actors
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: RPD found applicant did not demonstrate inability to access state protection
Crimes.Credibility: Found lacking due to omissions, inconsistencies, and embellishments
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Presumed adequate; applicant failed to rebut presumption
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Life and security risk from non-state actors
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Individual targeted due to alleged resistance to terrorist demands

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 97
Governing_Law: Regulations related to refugee protection and determination
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution as Roma and threats from Michaela's boyfriend; Board found boyfriend's threat unreliable, state protection adequate, and no distinct evidence warranting separate section 97 analysis
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies and omissions in applicants' statements
Procedural_Issue: Need for separate section 97 analysis assessed and rejected
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of credibility and state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of reliable evidence supporting boyfriend's threat
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants' claims lacking in credibility due to inconsistencies and omissions
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Board's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment
Decision_Rationale: Credibility findings reasonable, state protection available, no need for separate section 97 analysis due to lack of distinct evidence

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of deportation process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged collusion between Canada and U.S. to use deportation as disguised extradition
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, case precedents on disguised extradition
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No evidence of disguised extradition or irreparable harm; motion dismissed
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Canadian courts
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Lebanese citizen facing U.S. criminal charges
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Applicant's presence not conducive to public good
Crimes.Credibility: Claim deemed unsubstantiated due to lack of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Charter, IRPA provisions on admissibility
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Legal risk from deportation leading to foreign prosecution
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Canadian immigration authorities, alleged U.S.-Canada cooperation
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Individual subject to deportation with foreign criminal charges

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to foreign criminal offences
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of admissibility hearing fairness
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Bias by Board member, risk of self-incrimination, disguised extradition
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, precedent on bias and compelled testimony
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No evidence of bias or disguised extradition; hearing allowed to proceed
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Lebanese citizen with U.S. fraud convictions
Crimes.Credibility: Claims of bias and compulsion found premature or unsubstantiated
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Risk of removal based on foreign conviction

Crimes.Crime_Name: Compelling testimony concerns under Charter rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of potential Charter violations in immigration hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 7, IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of self-incrimination if compelled to testify
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Constitutional law, administrative law, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No actual compulsion yet; issue not ripe for review
Crimes.Credibility: Concerns acknowledged but not actionable at this stage

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Admissibility based on foreign fraud convictions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Potential self-incrimination and procedural fairness in admissibility hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No finding of dishonesty in application; focus on procedural issues
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 36(2)(a) – inadmissibility for serious criminality
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: U.S. fraud convictions rendering applicant inadmissible
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of final foreign criminal conviction
Crimes.Application_Factor: Foreign conviction as basis for inadmissibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings?
Outcome: The Member erred by not considering refugee hearings in assessing flight risk. Case remitted for redetermination.
Application_Error: Failure to consider relevance of refugee hearings in flight risk assessment
Legal_Standard: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention

Application_Facts: Applicants wanted in China for fraud, seeking refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider ongoing proceedings in detention decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider active refugee claims as a factor in flight risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention
Decision_Rationale: Focus on removal likelihood without considering refugee hearings was unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings as part of the flight risk analysis?
Evidence_Assessment: Member focused solely on removal likelihood
Legal_Rule: ID must assess flight risk and alternatives to detention, including upcoming proceedings
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous omission of relevant proceedings in flight risk analysis
Legal_Framework: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee protection decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in failing to conduct a proper s. 97 analysis and IFA finding?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision quashed and case remitted
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found not credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Evidence of LTTE risks in Colombo
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to conduct proper s. 97 analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of ongoing LTTE threats in Colombo
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Separate analysis required for subjective and objective elements
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal questions, patent unreasonableness for factual findings

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee protection decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in failing to conduct a proper s. 97 analysis and adequately address the IFA finding?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision quashed and case remitted
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claimants' subjective fear dismissed due to credibility concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Evidence of LTTE threats in Colombo
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to analyze objective risks in Colombo
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective risk assessment despite credibility issues
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of LTTE presence and threats in Colombo
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Separate analysis required for s. 96 and s. 97

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on fear of persecution
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision quashed and case remitted
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Membership in a particular social group targeted by LTTE
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention and Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Quashed and remitted to new panel
Crimes.Protected_Group: Persons targeted by LTTE for extortion
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Sri Lankan civilians subjected to LTTE coercion
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate state protection against non-state actors (LTTE)
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of extortion attempts by LTTE
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Insufficient government protection in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Extortion and threats based on perceived financial capacity

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat from individuals linked to terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Risk posed by applicants allegedly connected to LTTE
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Alleged involvement or targeting by LTTE
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Extortion, coercion, and threats by LTTE
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Claims of being targeted due to forced association
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Not applicable – applicants claimed victimhood, not leadership
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of corroboration for claims of LTTE targeting
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, country condition reports, news articles
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility findings by Board
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 34(1)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving national security concerns
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of protection and potential removal

Crimes.Victim_Status: Civilian individuals subjected to demands for money
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of threats and history of violence by LTTE
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicants attempted to comply to avoid harm
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: No indication of prior criminal behavior by applicants
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – linked to organized armed group activities
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk of harm if returned
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Threats of violence for failure to pay
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Individuals perceived as having financial resources
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence presented but not properly assessed by Board
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, incident descriptions, country condition reports
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Contested by Board due to credibility concerns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment by Board
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – civil proceeding, not criminal prosecution

Application_Facts: Mr. Khiamal alleged racial bias in Greyhound's hiring process, claiming he was not promoted to Foreman due to race, ethnic or national origin, and colour.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act challenging the Tribunal's dismissal.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of whether race was a contributing factor
Relief_Sought: Redress for alleged employment discrimination based on race and related grounds
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a differently constituted tribunal
Decision_Rationale: The Tribunal's decision was unreasonable due to errors in assessing animus, failing to consider discrimination as a factor, and ignoring relevant statistical data.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Permitting another person to use a passport
Crimes.Violation_Type: Permitting unauthorized use of travel document
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 10(2)(c) of the Canadian Passport Order SOR/81-86
Crimes.Application_Facts: The applicant's passport was used by imposters on two occasions. The applicant claimed the passport was lost, but evidence suggested she permitted others to use it.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Evidence indicated possible misrepresentation regarding loss and control of the passport
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found Passport Canada reasonably assessed credibility and concluded misuse occurred
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Revocation of passport and denial of services for five years upheld
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Passport Canada acted within its authority under Section 10(2)(c) and Section 10.2; decision supported by evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized use of passport by third parties with holder's implied consent
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 10(2)(c) and Section 10.2 of the Canadian Passport Order SOR/81-86
Crimes.Application_Facts: The applicant’s passport was used illegally by imposters twice. Despite claims of loss, evidence suggested the applicant was involved in or permitted the misuse.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Disputed claim of lost passport; suggestion of intentional or negligent facilitation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court accepted Passport Canada’s assessment that the applicant’s explanation lacked credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Revocation and five-year service denial deemed reasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; $2,000 costs awarded to respondent
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Declaration that the decision was unreasonable and restoration of passport rights
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Passport Canada had sufficient evidence to conclude misuse occurred; action taken was proportionate and lawful

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Respondent was physically absent from Canada for most of the three out of four years preceding the application; attended school in the U.S.; visited Canada during holidays but did not establish residence
Procedural_Issue: Minister appealed the citizenship judge's approval, leading to Federal Court review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of 'residence' under federal citizenship law
Evidence_Used: Travel records, school attendance in the U.S., visits to Canada during holidays
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating establishment of residence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged, but residence not established based on facts
Outcome: Citizenship judge's decision set aside; respondent must reapply after meeting residency requirement
Relief_Sought: Review of citizenship grant due to non-compliance with residency requirement
Remedy_Sought: Set aside of original decision and requirement to reapply upon fulfilling residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'reside' as physical presence and establishment in Canada under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Respondent did not meet the residency requirement as she was predominantly outside Canada and did not demonstrate residence despite periodic visits

Crimes.Crime_Name: Ministerial Relief Request under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of administrative delay
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Entitlement to mandamus order for delayed ministerial relief decision
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 35(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Draft recommendation ready by February 2010; no further progress despite submissions
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant demonstrated prima facie unreasonable delay
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Mandamus requires unreasonable delay, public legal duty, and no other adequate remedy
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable delay in processing ministerial relief request since 2008
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timeline of submissions, draft recommendation, government's time estimates
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law and IRPA provisions on ministerial relief
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Contested standing and argued against multiple mandamus orders
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Mandamus order to compel decision on ministerial relief
Crimes.Outcome: Mandamus granted; decision required within three months
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to association with a designated regime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions on inadmissibility (association with a foreign entity)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Principal applicant was part of Haiti’s judiciary linked to a designated regime
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Delay in processing ministerial relief application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Background checks, documentation of past role, internal government assessments
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found; delay not due to lack of evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility findings reported
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mandamus granted for relief decision; ancillary claims dismissed
Crimes.Outcome: Minister ordered to decide on relief within three months
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Prima facie unreasonable delay in administrative process
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Nearly three-year delay without justification constitutes unreasonable delay
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Confidentiality of government investigation report vs. applicant's right to fair process
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the CBSA's investigation report be declared confidential without infringing on the applicant's rights?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 151 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Outcome: Exhibit M-13 was sealed and declared confidential
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The report contained sensitive information that could harm ongoing proceedings if disclosed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Investigation report (Exhibit M-13) identifying individuals under investigation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation in border documentation leading to fraudulent refugee claim
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk of interference with other refugee claims due to disclosure
Crimes.Application_Error: Report was filed in error containing sensitive data
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious risk to an important interest and no reasonable alternatives
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Balancing public interest, fairness, and necessity for confidentiality
Crimes.Application_Factor: Sensitive nature of investigative content and potential for procedural harm
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Confidentiality order granted; access limited to legal counsel
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in immigration or border documents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Confidentiality of CBSA report vs. right to fair judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the CBSA's investigation report be declared confidential without infringing on the applicant's right to a fair judicial review?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 151 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Outcome: Report declared confidential with controlled access
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Disclosure could compromise investigative methods and third-party refugee claims
Crimes.Evidence_Type: CBSA investigation report on fraudulent refugee claim
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fraudulent entry into Canada through false statements
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Sensitivity of information and lack of redacted alternative
Crimes.Application_Error: Full report disclosed without prior redaction
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious risk to important interest and insufficiency of alternatives
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Fairness balanced against operational and procedural risks
Crimes.Application_Factor: Need to protect ongoing investigations and third-party privacy
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Report sealed; access permitted only to legal representatives
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fraudulent documents or statements to enter Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's decision is valid when considering an Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) without prior notice
Evidence_Type: Evidence that applicant’s parents safely relocated within Colombia
Basis_of_Claim: Claimant feared persecution if returned to original region in Colombia
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant was informed of IFA at the start of the hearing and had opportunity to respond
Application_Error: Alleged lack of prior notice on IFA issue
Application_Factor: Opportunity to address new issue during hearing
Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to provide adequate notice of Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Issue raised at beginning of hearing
Risk_Nexus: Connection between criminal activity and flight from home country
Evidence_Source: Testimony and documentary evidence regarding family relocation
Basis_for_Decision: Existence of safe Internal Flight Alternative and procedural fairness maintained
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Alleged lack of notice on IFA, found not to have occurred

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide adequate notice in refugee claims
Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of return; IFA raised at hearing start
Procedural_Issue: Timing of notice regarding Internal Flight Alternative
Evidence_Used: Relocation of applicant’s parents within Colombia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged lack of explicit reasoning on reasonableness of relocation
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of IFA
Decision_Rationale: Notice provided at hearing start sufficed; opportunity to respond granted

Application_Facts: Zhou provided passport stamps, credit card statements, bills, leases, and education records showing 1178 days of physical presence in Canada during the four years preceding his application
Residency_Compliance: Yes, 1178 days of physical presence documented, exceeding the 1095-day requirement
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge improperly applied a qualitative test instead of the statutory physical presence test
Evidence_Used: Passport stamps, credit card statements, utility bills, lease agreements, education records
Evidentiary_Deficiency: None; evidence was reliable and sufficient
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially denied by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by another Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: When an applicant meets the 1095-day physical presence requirement, the qualitative assessment of ties to Canada cannot override compliance with the statutory threshold
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), subject to review by Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Is punishment for illegal exit from Iran and a failed refugee claim considered persecution under the Convention refugee definition?
Outcome: CRDD's decision was overturned, and the case was sent back for reconsideration.
Legal_Provision: Punishment for illegal exit under a law of general application is not persecution unless there is evidence of excessive or extra-judicial punishment.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Donboli claimed refugee status due to fear of persecution in Iran based on political opinion and illegal exit.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk of severe or extra-judicial treatment upon return to Iran
Application_Error: CRDD erred by failing to consider if Mr. Donboli would face severe or extra-judicial treatment upon return, focusing instead on his ability to provide a cover story.
Evidence_Ignored: Risk of excessive or extra-judicial punishment for illegal exit
Legal_Standard: Punishment under a law of general application is not persecution unless it involves excessive or extra-judicial measures.
Application_Factor: Mr. Donboli's illegal exit and failed refugee claim
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review application allowed; case remitted for redetermination by a different panel.
Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border documents related to exit and refugee claim

Legal_Provision_Violated: Iranian immigration laws regarding lawful exit
Application_Facts: Mr. Donboli illegally exited Iran and fears persecution upon return.
Misrepresentation_Element: Failed refugee claim and attempt to re-enter Iran after illegal departure
Procedural_Issue: CRDD did not properly assess risk of persecution upon return
Evidence_Used: Details of illegal exit and prior refugee claim
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD failed to consider evidence of potential severe or extra-judicial treatment
Decision_Outcome: CRDD's decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution under the Convention requires more than punishment under a generally applicable law; must involve discriminatory or disproportionate treatment
Decision_Rationale: The risk of persecution must be assessed based on whether punishment for illegal exit would be excessive or applied in a persecutory manner

Application_Facts: Failures in managing mineral rights by the Crown, specifically related to fiduciary duties concerning mineral rights surrendered in the 1940s
Procedural_Issue: Motion for leave to amend the Statement of Claim
Decision_Outcome: Amendments allowed under Rule 201 as they arise from substantially the same facts as the original claim
Outcome: Amendments permitted; no prejudice to defendant; costs awarded appropriately
Relief_Sought: To include new particulars or causes of action in the Statement of Claim
Remedy_Sought: Leave to amend the Statement of Claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 201 of the Federal Court Rules
Decision_Rationale: The amendments are allowed because they arise from substantially the same facts as the original claim and serve the interests of justice, despite potential limitation period concerns

Violation_Type: Denial of refugee status based on assessment of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 96 or 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Shia convert from Pakistan who faced threats and violence due to religious conversion; claimed well-founded fear of persecution
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant was outside Canada when applying for protection
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on sectarian violence in Pakistan, state efforts to protect citizens
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant’s experiences credible but focused on availability of state protection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee, protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review overturning the Board’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution, meaningful and effective state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board concluded Pakistan provides meaningful state protection despite imperfect conditions; decision supported by evidence
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Was the IRB's decision to deny refugee status based on credibility and state protection grounds reasonable?
Outcome: The judicial review application was dismissed as there were no grounds to overturn the IRB's decision.
Credibility_Assessment: The IRB found significant omissions in the applicants' evidence, lack of corroboration, and failure to seek state protection.
Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disprove state protection availability
Legal_Standard: Standard of review for IRB decisions is patent unreasonableness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative decision review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the denial of Mr. Sylvester's transportation security clearance reasonable under the Aeronautics Act?
Crimes.Outcome: Application to set aside the denial was dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Sylvester's denials were found insufficient by the Advisory Body
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section allowing Minister to deny clearance based on reasonable belief
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Past allegations of theft affecting credibility
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Perceived risk to aviation security based on past conduct
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of alleged misconduct involving dishonesty
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in security clearance application context

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Employee with access to secure area
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Conduct occurred in aviation security-sensitive environment
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Charges withdrawn due to credibility issues
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Alleged but not proven theft in 1999
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Potential for unlawful interference with civil aviation
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Credible police report despite lack of conviction
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s denials lacked detail and were not persuasive

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative appeal of security clearance denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the denial of Mr. Sylvester's transportation security clearance reasonable based on the evidence provided?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Police report deemed credible despite no conviction
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities (lower than criminal standard)
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of detailed denial from applicant affected credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Minister may deny clearance if reasonable belief exists regarding aviation security risk
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Past allegations of theft and possession of stolen property
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Police report and applicant's response during review
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative decision-making under aviation security regulations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denied involvement, but explanations lacked detail
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Setting aside the denial of security clearance

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant alleged abuse by family members and sought refugee status in Canada
Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility concerns due to contradictions in testimony and implausibility of story
Procedural_Issue: Delay in filing the refugee claim
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence linking psychological state to fear of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility findings based on contradictions, implausibility, and delay
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Board's negative credibility determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was reasonable, supported by evidence, and not capricious; credibility issues justified denial

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk in Jamaica due to being openly lesbian
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of PRRA decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient corroborative evidence of sexual orientation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No serious credibility issue found
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Protection from deportation based on sexual orientation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement for hearing under IRPA when serious credibility issue exists
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision based on insufficient evidence, not credibility; no hearing required

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to criminal conviction
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged breach in not holding oral hearing
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Claimed risk due to sexual orientation upon return to Jamaica
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Insufficient evidence of sexual orientation; decision not based on credibility
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Application_Facts: Alleged bias due to relationships between board members and candidates; procedural violations in election processes
Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural violations in election processes
Principles of natural justice and procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: No evidence of actual bias or significant procedural flaws
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting bias or procedural impact
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Appeal Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of actual bias or significant procedural flaws impacting the election outcome; decision found to be fair and reasonable

Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision to deny permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds procedurally fair and reasonable?
Evidence_Assessment: The Officer used extrinsic evidence about education and health services without disclosing it.
Decision_Outcome: The application for judicial review is granted, the decision is set aside, and the case is remitted for redetermination by a different officer.
Legal_Rule: The Officer must consider hardships, best interests of the child, and avoid reliance on extrinsic evidence without giving the applicant a chance to respond.
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant claimed hardship upon return to her home country due to lack of support and potential threats.
Outcome_on_Merits: Insufficient analysis of the child's best interests; decision overturned.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Extrinsic evidence on education and health services, risks of abuse in home country
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, redetermination by a different officer
Outcome: Decision overturned, case sent back for reconsideration

Legal_Issue: Risk of torture or persecution upon deportation to India
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application for stay of removal
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA officer's findings supported by documentary evidence; Amnesty International reports submitted by applicant but not sufficient to overturn PRRA assessment
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate a serious issue to be tried or irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: PRRA officer found applicant's risk claims not credible; reliance on updated country conditions
Legal_Rule: Court must find a serious issue to be tried and irreparable harm for a stay; deference to PRRA officer's factual findings unless unsupported by evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged risk of torture and persecution in India due to political opinion or membership in particular social group
Outcome_on_Merits: No substantial risk of persecution or torture established
Key_Evidence_Considered: PRRA report, documentary country condition reports, Amnesty International reports
Legal_Framework: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA), Section 115 of IRPA, Article 3 of CAT
Defendant_Response: Immigration authorities maintained that country conditions in India have improved and applicant's claim lacks credibility
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, Country condition reports, NGO reports
Outcome: Stay denied; removal order remains enforceable

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff can amend its statement of claim to include newly registered copyrights without causing injustice to the defendant

Crimes.Evidence_Used: Membership in MQM-A and its alleged involvement in terrorism
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to define 'terrorism' or link specific acts to terrorist conduct
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on sufficiency of decision reasons
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer’s decision found patently unreasonable and set aside
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Challenging inadmissibility and denial of ministerial relief
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of admissibility by appropriate authority
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked adequate reasoning on definition and application of 'terrorism'
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer and Minister of Citizenship and Immigration

Crimes.Crime_Name: Subversion against a democratic government or institution
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged subversive activities through membership in MQM-A
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat from association with organization engaged in anti-state violence
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in MQM-A considered potentially subversive under Canadian standards
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Historical involvement of MQM-A in political violence in Pakistan
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Acts of violence and political destabilization attributed to MQM-A
Crimes.Target_Entity: Democratic institutions and processes in Pakistan
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Mr. Naeem admitted membership in MQM-A
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership role specified
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Sufficient evidence of organizational activity but insufficient linkage to individual subversion
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to explain how Mr. Naeem’s membership equated to engagement in subversion
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and intelligence-based evidence on MQM-A
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Focus on adequacy of reasoning rather than claimant credibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 34(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility decision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Section 34(1)(f)
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Membership in organization reasonably believed to engage in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Perceived risk from affiliation with designated terrorist entity
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Association with MQM-A during period of violent activity (1988–1999)
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Temporal overlap between membership and organization’s violent operations
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Acts of terrorism including violence and intimidation
Crimes.Target_Entity: Civilians and state institutions in Pakistan
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Mr. Naeem admitted membership in MQM-A
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No evidence of leadership role provided
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence of MQM-A’s activities accepted, but insufficient personal nexus established
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to define 'terrorism' or justify classification of MQM-A as terrorist
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, public records on MQM-A
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Decision undermined by lack of analytical rigor, not claimant dishonesty
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable belief standard under IRPA s. 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility and ministerial relief denial
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Initial denial of permanent residence; decision later set aside

Crimes.Crime_Name: Threat to the security of Canada
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Potential indirect threat via association with foreign terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Concerns about foreign-based terrorism influencing domestic security
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in MQM-A assessed as potential threat to Canadian security interests
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Global reach of terrorist networks and potential radicalization
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorist acts including bombings, assassinations, and armed conflict
Crimes.Target_Entity: Government and civilian targets in Pakistan
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of command or operational role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: General information on MQM-A available, but insufficient personalized assessment
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of explanation connecting membership to actual or likely threat to Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Focus on procedural deficiencies in decision-making process
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of national security inadmissibility
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility decision overturned due to unreasonableness

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Direct membership in group linked to terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Risk posed by individuals affiliated with proscribed organizations
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Affiliation with MQM-A during active phase of terrorist operations
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorism including targeted killings, bombings, and extortion
Crimes.Target_Entity: Political opponents, civilians, and state actors in Pakistan
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Organizational conduct documented, but inadequate personal attribution
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to define 'terrorism' or demonstrate that MQM-A meets legal threshold
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Public records, media reports, government assessments
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claimant not disbelieved; issue centered on decision logic
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable belief standard under IRPA s. 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to inadmissibility and procedural fairness
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Original decisions set aside; matter remitted for reconsideration

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged participation in or support of terrorist activities
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Direct threat from individuals involved in terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in MQM-A interpreted as potential engagement in terrorism
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Operational history of MQM-A involving systematic violence
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Acts of terrorism such as assassinations, bombings, and armed attacks
Crimes.Target_Entity: Civilian and governmental entities in Pakistan
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Membership admitted, but no direct participation in violent acts proven
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of operational or planning role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Background on organization established, but insufficient proof of personal engagement
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Absence of definition and application of 'terrorism' in decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not based on deception; hinges on legal interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Decisions set aside due to unreasonableness; case remitted

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Excessive demand on health or social services due to son's cerebral palsy
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Immigration officer's decision upheld as reasonable
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refusal of family admission based on health inadmissibility
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Applicant seeking admission with family member
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Potential excessive burden on public health and social services
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's financial plan deemed insufficiently credible
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Economic and systemic strain on public services
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Discrimination based on disability and family status

Crimes.Crime_Name: Excessive demand on health or social services
Crimes.Application_Facts: Son has cerebral palsy; applicant provided financial plan lacking specificity and credible arrangements for medical care
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant as parent of child with disability
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failure to meet admissibility requirements for permanent residency
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, specific evidence regarding long-term care funding and service access
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Plan relied on weak assumptions; deemed not credible by officer and court
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of general importance, reversal of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Excessive demand on health or social services
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded that the son’s condition could cause excessive demand on Canadian services

Perpetrator_Type: State or non-state actors involved in persecution
Aggravating_Factors: Systemic inadequacies in Mexican legal protections for domestic violence victims
Mitigating_Factors: Applicants provided explanations for missing documentation due to urgent flight from abuse
Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm if returned to country of origin
Targeted_Individual: Applicants as survivors of domestic violence
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient according to Board, but contextually explained by applicants
Evidence_Type: Affidavits or testimonies related to abuse
Lack of formal documentation due to fleeing
Evidence_Credibility: Disputed by Board despite plausible explanations
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable; failed to consider cultural and gender-related factors, dismissed explanations for missing evidence
Legal_Provision: Principles of procedural fairness and refugee protection under international law

Credibility_Assessment: efforts deemed insufficient by RPD

Risk_Assessment: risk of persecution or danger upon return
Credibility_Assessment: failure to fully pursue state protection undermined claim

Application_Facts: claim of past persecution and inadequate state protection in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: adequacy of efforts to seek state protection
Evidence_Used: documentary evidence on state protection in Mexico
Evidentiary_Deficiency: did not report all incidents to police
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found efforts insufficient
Decision_Rationale: adequate state protection exists in Mexico despite corruption

Risk_Assessment: risk to life and personal security upon return
Credibility_Assessment: delay and lack of reporting weakened claim

Aggravating_Factors: occurred in context of broader violence
Risk_Assessment: risk of further victimization upon return
Evidence_Credibility: credible but insufficient engagement with authorities
Credibility_Assessment: efforts to access protection deemed inadequate

Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient - CSC relied on reliable sources
Credibility_Assessment: Reliable information used
Sentencing_Issue: Life imprisonment with no parole for 25 years

Application_Facts: Tehrankari claimed false misconduct reports influenced classification
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under s.18.1 Federal Courts Act
Credibility_Assessment: CSC sources deemed reliable

Crimes.Crime_Name: Refusal to participate in a sexual offender assessment
Application_Facts: Assessment refusal cited as factor in classification
Misrepresentation_Element: Contested use of refusal as aggravating factor
Credibility_Assessment: CSC assessment process deemed credible
Decision_Rationale: Refusal considered within risk assessment framework

Governing_Law: Corrections and Conditional Release Regulations Section 18
Credibility_Factor: CSC's use of documented, reliable data
Legal_Rule: Classification must be based on accurate, complete information

Dispute_Type: Security classification based on inmate compatibility
Legal_Issue: Impact of incompatibility claims on classification
Evidence_Assessment: Minimal impact of escape risk on decision

Application_Facts: Tehrankari claimed escape risk was overstated
Procedural_Issue: Use of judicial review to challenge administrative decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minor inaccuracies did not affect outcome
Credibility_Assessment: Overall decision found credible
Decision_Rationale: Severity of crime outweighed minor discrepancies

Application_Facts: Challenge to adequacy of grievance resolution
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of CSC decisions
Credibility_Assessment: CSC process found credible
